benchmark_details.name: CRAB (Causal Reasoning Assessment Benchmark)
benchmark_details.overview: CRAB is a new Causal Reasoning Assessment Benchmark designed to evaluate causal understanding of events in real-world narratives. It includes fine-grained, contextual causality annotations for approximately 2,700 pairs of real-world events that describe various newsworthy event timelines, allowing evaluation of language models' performance on causal reasoning tasks.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To evaluate causal reasoning capabilities of large language models on real-world narratives through a structured benchmark.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The benchmark may contain biases due to the media's representations of events.

data.source: Causal events extracted from 173 news articles covering 20 stories from the past ten years.
data.annotation: Crowdsourced human annotations for causality judgments.

methodology.calculation: Causality scores are calculated on a scale from 0 to 100 based on human annotations.
methodology.interpretation: Scores are stratified into four classes reflecting causality strength.
methodology.baseline_results: GPT-4 achieved an average F1 score of approximately 54.7 in pairwise causality tasks.
methodology.validation: Validated by human experts through an additional annotation phase.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: The benchmark includes annotations reflecting potential biases in media representation.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.consent_procedures: Data was collected via public news articles; specific consent procedures are not discussed.
